Surface radar. Made radar contact range 8,500 yards.
Targets proceeding on steady course and speed north
of Muko Jima. Largest pip was in center with one
smaller pip on his starboard quarter and one very
sharp on his port bow distance about 400 yards.
In sight as vague blurs out 6,000 yards. Figured
he was:
(a) Submarine trap.
(b) Mine sweepers.
(c) Cripple in tow.
(d) Sampan convoy.
Decided to attack with torpedoes set for shallow
draft. Because visibility made periscope attack
impracticable and consideration for possibility (a)
above dictated that I not drift back on him dead in
water, decided to attack with bow tubes at speed.
Estimated from size of pip etc. that he must draw
at least 7 feet so set 6 feet depth. By the time
we were in firing position had him taped so that
TDC was tracking him perfectly. The only adjust-
ment necessary for a period of one hour being the
exact firing bearings. Came in from starboard bow
and fired with a 2,300 yard run. He was well in
sight at this time and was seen to be large schooner
rigged vessel and two trawlers. He was very high
out of water and length estimated at 200 feet by
binocular formula. No big guns observed. When he
did nothing as two torpedoes passed under him decided
he had no sound gear and was a good subject for gun
attack.

TARGET DATA - DAMAGE INFLICTED
XAM 400 ton converted trawler, coastal minesweeper.
Similar to center picture, patrol craft, ONI 41-42,
radio equipped, armed with depth charges and machine
guns. - C.
DAMAGE DETERMINED BY: Left blazing amidships and aft. Exploded
and sunk as we were leaving scene of action.
DETAILS:
Sighted by lookout at 12,000 yards in bright moonlight
lying to on surface. He was identified as converted
trawler with high radio masts. Could see no large guns,
so manned deck gun and closed to 5,000 yards. Opened
fire. He turned away and ran so closed him firing 2
or 3 shots every 500 yards. Made 2 or 3 hits with no
apparent effect. At 2,800 yards hit with high capacity
shell knocked off his bridge, stack, and guns and set
his dock house afire. He lost control and weaved
crazily. Sound had his scrows and we tracked him at
At 2,000 yards we stopped him with another
high capacity hit. Closed to 700 yards using 4", 20mm
and 50 calibors. He caught fire midships and aft and
the ammunition in his magazine aft began exploding.
He had two depth charges topside. These exploded as
we cleared the area and he sunk. He was picked up by
radar at 9,000 yards.
Expended:
4" - 54 rounds.
20mm - 1320 rounds.
50 cal. - 260 rounds.
SJ radar ranges were used until ho was at point blank
range.

One 600 ton patrol vessel flying Jap naval ensign, one

DAMAGE DETERMINED BY: Left patrol vessel riddled with 4", 20mm
and 50 cal. fire, and blazing fore and aft, sending up
loud explosions intermittenly, and lighting up the
whole horizon with its glow. One trawler exploded and

DETAILS:
CONFIDENTIAL
Aftor torpedo attack No. 5 withdrew to 6,000 yards on
quarter of target group and manned all guns. The
largest target had taken position between us and the
other two so we attacked him first. Closed range on
constant bearing keeping him well on bow to prevent
his turning in and ramming. Commenced firing as soon
as he was in sight at gun range 1,000 yards. Sprayed
him with 50 cal. at same time. Simultaneously took
nearost other vessel undor fire with forward 20mm.
First 4" shot Immocked off his bridge and machine guns.
50 Cal. fire swept all personnel from the decks.
nine minutos he was flaming fore and aft and sinking.
He flew a Jap naval onsign which would have been a real
prize to bring back but it too, went up in the con-
flagration. During our firing on the patrol vessel the
two trawlers were proceeding about 50 yards apart on
parallel course. We attacked the nearest of the two.
After four minutes a 4" high capacity shell hit him
and ho disintegrated in a cloud of smoke and steam.
Had kopt on quarter of this group while firing to pre-
vent ramming but last trawler took advantage of the
smoke screen presented by his exploding pardner to
turn and head in to ram. As he came out of smoke cloud
I gave right full rudder and went ahead flank in an
attempt to make the best of a bad situation. Had
secured the 4" gun and put crew under cover when the
second ship blew up as we were getting close enough
for real execution by machine guns and I didn't want
too many men exposed. Both 20mm guns and 50 cal. guns
took this occasion to jam. The trawler came on in
with a machine gun firing wildly from his bow. We had
picked up enough speed and gotten far enough around
when he hit so that damage was negligible. His bow
sprit crumpled up against our armored bridge. He

Mines
North of Iwo Jima on 9 July we sighted a mine-layer being
escorted to that island (Ship Contact #2). There is a strong
pos ibility that this was the "Coastal Vessel" reported sunk by
the aircraft strike on Iwo Jima a few days later, but its presence
shows that the Japs contemplated mine operations.
Due to strong irregular currents prevailing between Muko Jima,
Chichi Jima and Haha Jima there is little probability of mines.
On 26 July we twice crossed the 100 fathom curve north of Chichi
Jima in search of a contacted convoy. Currents up to 2½ knots
were encountered. Also a steady use of these areas by sampans
indicate that no mine field is present.

ANTI-SUBMARINE MISURES AND EVASION TACTICS
Anti-submarine measures observed in this area consisted
of a daily plane patrol, usually about the middle of the day
and of surface escorts and a single close air screen for con-
voys. KATES were used for close air screen. On the convoy
just missed the first of Auust we were driven down by a
SALLY which was evidently a distant screen. No. air cover
was provided at night.
Each convoy had one warship escort and one or more large
sampan types by the time we saw them. Escorts seemed to
listen as no pinging was heard prior to attacks. From the
time it took the depth charge attack to develop after tor-
pedo fire it is believed that the warship initiated all
attacks.
I decided temperature gradient aided evasion. We went
to 300 feet and headed away on the normal escape course at
85 RPM in cach case. After the attack of the thirteenth,
escorts were banging away merrily and dropping aft when we
attempted to come up to periscope depth, as we approached the
gradient, 150 feet he evidently hoard us as he immodiately
headed toward and his charges came much closer. He matched our
every change of course until we went back to 300 feet.

MAJOR DEFECTS
D.
BUSHIPS.
GENERAL MOTORS 278-A ENGINIS - As a result of mass production the
connecting rod bearings on these engines are no longer precision
built. Recognition of this fact caused the engineering department
to put in many extra hours inspecting the bearings. The bearings
of several units are slightly pitted but are still satisfactory.
The same amount of work put in inspecting these bearings on board
ship would make lots of precision bearings if applied at the
factory.
PIT LOG - High speed end of the transtat assembly winding arced
out during depth charging, fusing about 6 loops. Cause: Salt
water on coil, but source of salt water undetermined. To repair,
the damaged loops were stripped back to good insulation and the
coil was tapped off at that point. Operation normal except that
the instrument maximum was cut from 25 to about 23 knots.
SD MOTOR GENERATOR - The motor generator speed regulator had to
be readjusted and bad brushes changed. Routining this unit is
difficult as it is necessary to pull the end bells to clean it
properly. The two small inspection plates installed are not large
enough to permit the brushes to be seen.
AMMUNITION 26mm - Frequent jamming was experienced with the 20mm
guns, This usually occured during the first shots from a new
magazine. It is believed that defective ammunition was causing
the jams. All the magazines were loaded with 2 B.L.P. projectiles
for the first two shots. This ammunition was drawn from the
Submarine Base, Balboa, C.Z., May 17, 1944, and is designated

Radio reception was generally good. On July 22, attempts
to clear traffic on 12705 Kos and 8470 Kcs was hampered by Jap
CW interference. Traffic was cleared on 4235. The only material
failures during the patrol were old RF tubes in the RAK-6 and
RAL-6 equipment.
In a radio room arrangement which allows only one operators
position it is extremely difficult to cover two frequencies at
the same time. As this condition often occurs, a rearrangement
is indicated and we will accomplish it as soon as practical.

N - SOUND
The supersonic sound gear gavo satisfactory performance
throughout the entire patrol. It is felt that all ranges were
below par for this equipment which in most cases may have been
due to water conditions. On different occasions patrol vessels
were located by sound at 5,000 to 6,000 yards when running at
slow speed.
Enemy underwater echo ranging was encountered on two occasions
on 17.4 Kcs and 14.7 Kcs. As they closed they changed from 6
second to 3 second intervals on their keying. The only material
difficulty encountered was in the QB training motor, the rubber
buffers to the clutch which fit into the rotating gear became
chewed badly and slipped out. No spares are furnished, so tem-
porary repairs were made.

(3) The Commander-in-Chief, U. S. Pacific Fleet.
U.S.S. COBIA First War Patrol - Comment on.
The first war patrol of the COBIA was conducted off
the Bonin Islands. Twenty-nine days were spent on station out of
a total of forty-eight days from port to port.
2.
The area was well covered and every opportunity to
inflict damage on the enemy was explored exhaustively and with
outstanding success:
ATTACK No. 1.
An armed enemy patrol vessel of 400 tons, sighted in the
moonlight at a range of 12000 yards, was engaged on the surface
and sunk by gunfire. Radar ranges were used for fire control.
This attack took place on July 6, two days prior to COBIA's arrival
in the patrol area.
ATTACK No. 2.
On July 9, a submerged attack on a coastal mine layer was
frustrated when a screening plam obtained a near miss on the sub-
marine at periscope depth. The resultant shock deranged the tor-
pedo control mechanism and the one torpedo fired ran wide of the
target. COBIA was counter-attacked by the FUBUKI escort over a
period of one hour during which 26 depth charges were dropped.
ATTACK No. 3.
On the morning of July 13, one of a pair of naval auxili-
aries, carefully identified as AF's of the NOSHIMA MARU class,
was sunk with two well placed torpedo hits from a bow salvo of
three shots. Both hits were observed by periscope and although
the target was not seen to sink, there is very strong evidence
that it did. COBIA withstood a counter-attack of 45 charges
dropped by the three escorts.

First War Patrol - Comment on.
1
ATTACK No. 4.
An escorted freighter, identified as similar to the KISO
MARU, was attacked with four torpedoes on the surface on the night
of July 17-18. Two hits were obtained and the target was observed
to sink within five minutes. COBIA turned away after firing and
eluded the escorts without difficulty.
ATTACK No. 5.
Early the next morning, COBIA again demonstrated her mettle
with an all out submerged attack on a large freighter of the
ARIZONA MARU class. Six bow shots down the throat produced two
hits. The submarine then swung off the track and fired her four
stern tubes to obtain two more hits, this time in the screws of
the target. The three escorts, led by a CHIDORI, applied a 70
charge treatment to COBIA's hull during the next hour, but little
material damage was sustained. The decision of the commanding
officer to concentrate his torpedoes upon the one large target
rather than share them with the accompanying AK, is considered
sound, and there is strong evidence that this ARIZONA MARU sank.
ATTACK No. 6.
A night surface torpedo attack on July 20 during which two
torpedoes ran under the target, was converted into a gun battle.
Three small, armed vessels were destroyed during a half-hour
fight, characterized by expert work on the part of the COBIA gun
crows, During this engagement, COBIA was rammed amidships by one
of the trawlers but a quick turn away reduced the collision to a
glancing blow which prevented the submarine hull from being
punctured. Superstructure framing and plating in the vicinity of
frames 52 to 56, port, were stove in and the outer hull was dimpled
between frames 55 and 56.
ATTACK No. 7.
The final attack of the patrol occurred on August 5, when
COBIA intercepted a converted yacht and quickly dispatched it with
one torpedo hit in the stern. A minute later, the sinking vessel
was strafed by our own aircraft. COBIA then surfaced and selected
a sample prisoner from the score of uniformed Japes floundering in
the water; he turned out to be a Sea Bee.

Forwarded, concurring in the remarks and recom-
mendations contained in the first endorsement.
2.
COBIA's first ar patrol was characterized by
agressiveness and clear thinking, both of which paid dividends.
The gun attack on July 20 was particularly well executed, and is
indicative of the fighting qualities of officers and crew.
3.
Upon arrival at Majuro, personnel were in high spirits.
and in good physical condition. So far as cleanliness was con-
cerned, the ship was ready for a peace time Saturday morning
inspection.
4. The commanding officer has been acquainted with
current procedure in recommending awards. Conformity therewith
should cover the case of DeVEY, R. F., F2c, who is recommended
for the Bronze Star.
5.
The prisoner was delivered into the custody of the
Atoll Commander at Majuro.
6.
This is the second submarine within a week to arrive
in lajuro after a successful first patrol, for refit and adminis-
tration by this squadron. Other new submarines seem to be doing
well, also. The whole appears to be good evidence that our basic
training methods are sound.
7.
Commander Submarine Squadron Ten congratulates the
commanding officer, officers and men for an excellent patrol.

U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of First War Patrol.
(26 June to 14 August 1944).
The first war patrol of the COBIA and the first for the
commanding officer as such, was conducted off the Bonin Islands.
2.
This first war patrol started with the sinking of the
first enemy contact, a 400 ton armed trawler, in a nicely executed gur
attack. This splendid start was followed by four successful torpedo
attacks out of six tries and another daring and successful gun attack,
The some 140 odd depth charges and the glancing blow from the bow of a
trawler during the second gun attack received by the COBIA without
serious damage, is ample proof of the determination and courage of the
officers and men in her and the sturdy construction of the ship.
3.
Insignia Award.
This patrol is designated as "Successful" for Combat
4.
The Commander Submarine Force, Pacific Fleet, congratu-
lates the commanding officer, officers, and crew for this fighting and
highly successful first patrol. The COBIA is credited with having in-
flicted the following damage upon the enemy:
